rows.text_1:
**Learning about the family, child, and relationship between parent and child.**
You should use individual consultations as an opportunity to learn as much as you can about the family circumstances and challenges. This is important as when a parent begins to change the way that they interact with the children in the household, it will affect everyone else and can sometimes generate conflict. 
 
This conversation will provide you with a greater understanding of some of the challenges that families are experiencing at home. It will also equip you with information that might be useful in helping parents to establish weekly goals and solve issues that arise when parents practice new skills at home.

**Identifying an overall goal for the programme.**
It is also important that you help parents to identify ONE positive, specific, and realistic goal for their target child during the programme.

To help parents set a goal, it is important that you ask parents to describe their expectations about the programme. In doing this, help them identify a specific goal about how they would like to change their relationship with their child or their child’s behaviour.

text_2.eng:
**Suggested Structure for Individual Consultations before Group Sessions:**
A. Introduce yourselves to the parent and the whole family if present.
B. Provide an overview of programme (This can just be the basics such as how the programme will help them with their own and their child’s behaviour)
C. Ask about the family environment at home: 
What is happening at home?
Who else lives there? How many children are there? Husband/Wife? Partner? Grandparents?
Who else provides care for children?
What kind of support do you already receive from close friends and family members that you can trust nearby?

D. Discuss with the parent about his/her relationship with their child:
If the programme is being delivered as part of a study: 
Remind the parent that they will be focusing on the target child selected during the assessment.
If the parent has not selected a specific child to focus on during the programme: 

Ask the parent to select one child to focus on during the programme. This child should be between the ages of 2 and 17 years old. If the parent has more than one child between this age range, s/he should select the child with whom s/he is having the most difficult relationship or challenges when managing the child’s behaviour. 

You can also reassure the parent that the skills learned in the programme may be applicable to all of the other children in his/her family, but that s/he should focus on this one child during the group discussions and home practice.
What is life like at home with your child?
What is your relationship with your child like?
What are some challenges that you are facing in terms of managing your child’s behaviour?
Are there other challenges that make it difficult to be a parent?

E. Parent Goals for the Programme
What are your goals, expectations, or hopes for you and your child in general and from this programme? 
Help the parent identify ONE the specific, positive, and realistic goal.
Write the parent’s goal down at the bottom of your participant/parent profile.

F. Discuss practicalities
Timing of the li
Platform that will be used for ParentChat (and how to download the app if they do not already have it)
Needs for airtime/data load
Other technological questions that are related to participating in the programme. What is the participant’s digital literacy? Do participants know how to open messages? Respond?
Clarify literacy level of parents – you may need to send audio messages instead of text messages if parents have difficulty reading. You may need to explain how a participant listens to an audio message.

G. Any other questions?

rows.text_1: The first step to building healthier and happier relationships is to spend dedicated time together. When parents spend one-on-one time with their children away from work and household duties and other people, they create space to be available to their child, to get more involved in their lives, and to build trust and communication skills. A strong parent-child relationship requires spending time together in this way.

When parents spend one-on-one time with their children away from work and household duties and other people, they create space to be available to their child, to get more involved in their lives, and to build trust and communication skills. A strong parent-child relationship requires spending time together in this way.

rows.text_1:
**Key building blocks for instructions**

The key building blocks for One-on-One time are Day, Play, and Stay:

'’DAY’’- Try to do it every day
Spend 5 minutes (or more!) One-on-One time with your child each day.

‘’PLAY’’ - Let them choose the activity
Tell your child or teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy this time with you!

‘’STAY’' - Focus on your child or teen
Switch off TV and put aside phones. Look at your child or teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

text_2.eng:
Here are some more One-on-One Time building blocks for parents with children aged 2–9:

Use words to describe what your child is doing during One-on-One Time – it shows you are paying attention to them and helps build vocabulary for younger children,

Allow your child to take the lead during One-on-One time.

Allow your child to invite you into their world by showing interest in what they are doing.

Accept and observe instead of asking questions and criticising your child when playing.

Play at your child’s developmental level and pace.

Find ways of playing together instead of competitive games during One-on-One time.

More One-on-One time building blocks for parents with adolescents:

One-on-One time means giving your full attention to your teen.

Allow your teen to talk to lead in a conversation or activity.

Look at your teen while they are speaking.

Show interest in their story and acceptance of their feelings.

rows.text_1:
** Key issues to be aware of**

In this first module it’s important to create a welcoming space for everyone. 

Ground rules should be developed at the beginning of the programme and owned by the group – so everybody should agree. 
- Try to help parents make specific rules. 
- Make sure everybody in the group understands each rule and what is required of the group.
- Help parents to make positive rules! Instead of ‘no criticising’ try ‘provide supportive feedback’.
- Give parents a chance to debate the rules that are being suggested. This will help everyone to own the final set of rules. 
- Praise suggestions!

**Praise & confidence building**: Remember that just like speaking up in a group for the first time, parents might be feeling nervous. Give parents as much positive reinforcement and thanks for sharing as you can on day one. 

**Normalising difficult households**: Make sure you remind parents that no household is perfect! We all have problems and challenges – praise parents regularly for being here because they want to put in the work to change something for the better. 

**Confidentiality:** This means that what gets said or circulated in the group, stays in the group! It’s important to be clear right at the beginning what is okay to share with others outside the group and what is not. In order for people to feel comfortable enough to participate, they need to know that they can trust the group with the stories they are sharing – and that these will not be shared outside of the group. Sharing new positive information is absolutely fine, though! 

If there is a need to break confidentiality, it is because a parent has disclosed or has shown evidence or significant risk of harm to themselves or their children (physical, emotional, or physical). The facilitator needs to break confidentiality if there is a risk of self-harm or harm to others. When this happens, the facilitator will ensure that they communicate directly in private with the person in question.

rows.text_1: **Overview of module topic: talking about feelings**

text_1.eng: **Overview of module topic: talking about feelings**

text_2.eng:
Happiness, sadness, anger, disgust, surprise, and fear: We all experience emotions. Because emotions are connected to our thoughts and behaviour, they play an important role in how we make decisions. If we don’t handle emotions well, we risk making bad decisions that can affect our well-being. And when we learn how to handle our emotions, we are more likely to be able to make clear decisions and act in a responsive and nurturing way towards our children, other adults, and ourselves.

Young people who don’t manage their emotions can resort to risky behaviours that can be dangerous for them. It is important for parents to learn to help their children to recognise and manage their strong emotions. 

Talking about difficult emotions is especially important. Difficult emotions like anger can become stressful thoughts and uncontrolled behaviours. Before we can talk about the emotions we are experiencing, just being aware of them can help us to stay present in a moment, which will allow the feelings to run their course and pass. This is also true for children.

When parents name their children’s feelings, or comment on them, it helps children to develop a sense of emotional control. Parents can accept their children’s emotions and communicate with them about what they are experiencing in a calm and supportive way. This will reduce other more potentially risky ways children might turn to in order to escape the feeling.

During Module Two, parents learn about the importance of accepting, naming, and exploring a range of emotions with their children. They learn techniques that will help them to do this effectively. 

**The primary objectives for this week are parents learning and practicing how to talk about their own and their children’s feelings.**

rows.text_1: **Key building blocks for talking about emotions**

text_1.eng: **Key building blocks for talking about emotions**

text_2.eng:
The key building blocks for Talking about Emotions are Breathe, Share, Listen, Show, and Seek:

BREATHE. Slowly. Pause. 
Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out. It will calm you and give you a chance to think.

SHARE how you feel
This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress. 

LISTEN to your child or teen
Allow your child to share their emotions. You can also reflect back what they say to you. Accept that the feeling is okay, even if it is negative.

SHOW them you care
This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our children and teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say, ‘I understand.’ It can change everything.

SEEK the positive
Can you and your child or teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?

rows.text_1: **Overview of module topic: Keeping it positive**

text_1.eng: **Overview of module topic: Keeping it positive**

text_2.eng:
The objective of this week is to learn how parents can be more effective at getting their children to follow their instructions. They do this in two ways: 

1️⃣Giving specific, positive, and realistic instructions
2️⃣Praising their children for following instructions and at other times

When parents give specific, positive, and realistic instructions, children know exactly what behaviour is expected from them. 

For example, “Please put your toys away in the box.” This tells the child exactly what to do by describing the behaviour that is expected. It also considers the capabilities of the child so that the instruction is realistic. 

Compare this to, “Don’t make a mess,” which does not describe the behaviour that a parent would want to see, is not specific, and might not be realistic if the child is not capable of keeping tidy. 

Children also have challenges following many instructions at one time – especially younger children. They are much better at following instructions if they are given one at a time.  Parents can pause for a bit to give children time to follow each instruction before moving to the next one. It may take more time, but this supports children to follow instructions and to remember the task.  

Each child has their own unique characteristics and capabilities. It is important that parents know what is realistic for their children to do when giving them instructions. For instance, it is very hard for children to keep quiet for a whole day but maybe they can keep quiet for 15 minutes while their parents take a call.  

Children also hear better and understand the instructions clearly when parents speak in a calm voice. Yelling at children only increases the tension for everyone. Children are also more likely to follow instructions in a calm way.

Praise is an expression of approval or appreciation. When parents praise their children for following instructions, they are encouraging that behaviour to happen more often. The same works for praising other behaviours. Also, behaviour that is ignored is less likely to happen again. 

With the example above, a parent could say, “Thank you for putting your toys in the box, Joseph,” after he follows the instruction. This will encourage Joseph to continue cleaning up his toys in the future. It also maintains a positive feeling between the parent and Joseph.

rows.text_1: **Key building blocks for giving instructions**

text_1.eng: **Key building blocks for giving instructions**

text_2.eng:
The key building blocks for giving instructions are Be Positive, Be Specific, and Be Real:

1️⃣Know the positive behaviour you want to see from your child.
2️⃣Make sure to have your child’s attention when giving an instruction.
3️⃣Give one instruction at a time. 
4️⃣Give your child time to follow each instruction.
4️⃣Make sure your child is able to follow your instruction.
5️⃣For younger children, break one big task into small ones and give instructions step by step. 
6️⃣Praise your child immediately after following an instruction.

rows.text_1: **Key building blocks for praise**

text_1.eng: **Key building blocks for praise**

text_2.eng:
The key building blocks for Praise are SEE IT, SAY IT, REPEAT IT:

1️⃣ SEE IT. Notice anything your child does that is helpful or good and praise them. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

2️⃣SAY IT. Be enthusiastic - really mean it when you say it!

4️⃣ REPEAT IT. Try to find something every day to thank them for. Even something really small.

rows.text_2:
The key building blocks for Praise are SEE IT, SAY IT, REPEAT IT:

1️⃣ SEE IT. Notice anything your child does that is helpful or good and praise them. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

2️⃣SAY IT. Be enthusiastic - really mean it when you say it!

4️⃣ REPEAT IT. Try to find something every day to thank them for. Even something really small.

rows.text_1: **Overview of module topic: Keeping your child safe with household rules and daily routines**

text_1.eng: **Overview of module topic: Keeping your child safe with household rules and daily routines**

text_2.eng:
Parents sometimes get frustrated at their children for being noisy or not tidying up after they have played, throwing their food on the ground, or staying out way too late. Often children don’t understand why these things are important. Establishing and explaining household rules helps children understand what is expected of them and why. Rules also establish clear boundaries that help children to feel safe and secure.

Routines also help children to feel safe and secure. Routines such as mealtimes and bedtimes can help create a stable environment for children. This is especially important for those who are living in hectic or unsafe environments and communities. 

**In this module, parents focus on the importance of involving their children when establishing household rules and routines to help keep their children safe and healthy.**

rows.text_1: **Key building blocks for rules and routines**

text_1.eng: **Key building blocks for rules and routines**

text_2.eng:
The key building blocks for establishing household rules and routines are:

1️⃣Be a Team. Create rules with your child or teenager. One rule at a time is easiest. Discuss the reasons for the rule and listen to their views. 

2️⃣Keep It Real. Make them realistic for what your child or teenager can do and be clear and specific so there’s no misunderstanding. Not ‘on time’ but ‘by 7pm’. 

3️⃣Be Consistent. Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security that they need to grow and develop.

4️⃣Praise, Praise, Praise. Praise your child or teen for making a rule with you and praise them for keeping it!

text_2.eng:

4️⃣Praise your child for following through with each instruction. 

5️⃣Bedtime and mealtime routines should be predictable and calm.

6️⃣Make a schedule so caregivers can share responsibilities.

rows.text_1: **Overview of module topic: Problem solving with children and final reflection**

text_1.eng: **Overview of module topic: Problem solving with children and final reflection**

text_2.eng:
The last module of the @global.app_name programme is about reflection and sharing. This final module is a bit longer than normal as you will help parents to reflect on their experiences during the programme and make specific plans on how they want to go forward without your facilitation.

The module starts with an opportunity to learn one final parenting skill – involving your children in solving problems. Throughout the entire programme, you have been modelling the key steps of solving problems with the parents.
There are 5 key steps in problem solving:
1️⃣Identify the problem
2️⃣Jointly come up with solutions
3️⃣Choose a solution
4️⃣Try the solution out
5️⃣Reflect on whether the solution worked

Each week during the discussion on home activities and illustrated stories, the parents have used the same steps in problem solving to help identify and practice solutions to challenges experienced.

Teaching children how to solve their own problems is a skill that children will take with them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!
In the second part of the module, parents have the opportunity to reflect on the changes they have seen in their families and the experiences that they have had during the programme. They can share how they have changed and what they have noticed about how their children’s behaviours may have changed.

This is also an opportunity to discuss how parents can continue using the skills and building blocks they have practiced over the course of the programme. Weekly chats have enabled parents to get to know each other and to support each other. That support doesn’t need to end! With a new administrator of the group, the chat group can be used whenever anybody needs to reach out or check-in. 

This week’s programme objectives are therefore to reflect and identify how to keep the programme going in a parent-lead group. We cover these topics for just one day this week: today!

text_2.eng:
The key building blocks for Problem Solving:

KNOW IT. Identify the problem

SOLVE IT. Think of possible solutions and what their results would be. 

TRY IT. Choose one solution and try it out 

TEST IT. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.

rows.text_1: Record the following audio message.

text_1.eng: Record the following audio message.

text_2.eng:
You may want to close your eyes and sit comfortably while you listen to this message.

Take a moment to think about what your lives and children were like before the programme began.

Now think about each of the parts of the ParentChat programme:

Spending One-on-One time with your child

Talking about feelings

Keeping it positive with praise and instructions

Involving your children in making household rules and daily routines

Using positive discipline like redirect and consequences

Involving your children in solving problems

Think about how the things you learned during the programme were different from the way you interacted with your children before the programme.

Think about how you have changed, how your relationship to your children has changed, and how your children’s behaviours have changed.

When you are ready, you can open your eyes.
